phrase.item: Once upon a time, there was a man.
He had neither livelihood nor fortune.
One day he thought and said, "I will go to mullah and check my destiny and fortune."
Then he went for a journey.
On the way he came across an apricot tree.
He [the apricot tree] said, "Hey God's male creator, where are you going?"
He said, "To check my destiny and fortune."
The apricot tree told him, "Check for me too; in spring I make flowers, then unripe apricots, my fruits don't get ready and they fall, I wonder why?"
The man said, "Okay."
He went, [and] on the way he met a beautiful girl.
The girl asked him, "Hey traveler, where are you going?"
The man said, "To check my fortune [luck in life]".
The girl said, "Check for me as well, I also don't have [any] fortune".
Then the man went and [saw] a sick tiger.
He [the tiger] asked the man, "Where are you going?"
The man said, "To check my fortune [luck in life]".
The tiger told him, "Check for me too; what remedy works for me?"
Then the man reached the mullah and told him his complaint.
The mullah said, "Now your fortune will open (will get better), your life [condition] will also get better."
The man told him the apricot [tree]'s complaint as well.
The Mullah said, "Under that apricot [tree] there are big bags of gold buried. That's why its fruits fall," and said, "if someone takes them out, then the fruits are not going to fall."
And he told the girl's complaint.
The Mullah said, "Her fortune is also going to open (will get luck in getting married)."
Lastly, he told the tiger's [complaint].
The Mullah said about the tiger, "His remedy is a foolish man's head."
To make the story short, the man returned.
He came next to the apricot [tree].
He [tree] said, "How are you doing?"
The man said, "Everything is good."
He [the tree] asked again, if he [man] asked about him [apricot tree] as well.
The man said, "Under you, there are bags of gold burried.
Whenever it will be taken your fruit will get ready (ripen) till the end."
The apricot [tree] asked him, "Why don't you take it for yourself?"
The man said, "Oh no, my life will get better very soon."
Then he went and reached where the girl was.
The girl asked him how he was doing.
He said, "Well, it will become good." The girl asked, "Did you ask about me?"
[He] said, "Yes, he said that your fortune will open (will get luck for marriage) as well."
The girl said, "Why don't you marry me?"
The man said, "Oh no, I will get my fortune (luck for marriage) soon."
Then he left.
He came to the tiger.
The tiger asked him, "How are you doing?"
He said, "Everything is fine with me, and I asked about you, your madicine is a foolish man's brain."
The tiger asked him again, "Did you meet anyone else on the way?"
The man said, "I checked for a girl and an apricot [tree] as well".
The tiger asked again, "What was the answer?'
He said, "The girl will get her luck for marriage,
under the apricot [tree] there are bags of gold burried, when they are taken out, it's fruit will be ready".
The tiger thought that there is no more foolish person than this man.
The girl was his fortune for marriage, the gold was his life, and he didn't take them.
Then he [tiger] asked, "Can you get closer to me?'
The man came closer.
The tiger took off his head and ate his brain, and his sickness went away.
